thread.title: Mets' Noah Syndergaard confident Cubs will see him in different light - Chicago Tribune
thread.title_full: Mets' Noah Syndergaard confident Cubs will see him in different light - Chicago Tribune

author: Colleen Kane
title: Mets' Noah Syndergaard confident Cubs will see him in different light - Chicago Tribune
text:
Noah Syndergaard's major-league debut against the Cubs earlier this season may not provide the proper perspective on the pitcher the Cubs will face in Game 2 of the National League Championship Series on Sunday.
The 23-year-old Mets right-hander said he has "changed night and day" since he gave up three earned runs on six hits and four walks in 5 1/3 innings for his first career loss on May 12.
"We made a lot of improvements and … and implemented a secondary changeup grip, which has allowed huge strides for my career," Syndergaard said. "My mechanics are completely different. My mentality is a lot different. I have a lot more confidence in myself and getting myself out of certain situations."
In Syndergaard's debut, Chris Coghlan went 1-for-2 with a walk and home run, but Cubs manager Joe Maddon wasn't sure he would adjust the lineup to insert Coghlan on Sunday.
"I like where (Jorge) Soler is at, but we'll see how it plays out," Maddon said.
The Cubs also don't have many left-handed hitters off the bench with Miguel Montero expected to catch Jake Arrieta, so Coghlan could be more valuable in that role.
Syndergaard finished the year 9-7 with a 3.24 ERA and 166 strikeouts in 150 innings. He pitched twice in the division series against the Dodgers, taking a Game 2 loss after allowing three earned runs and striking out nine in 61/3 innings. He also made his first career relief appearance to help the Mets lock down the series, pitching a scoreless seventh with two strikeouts in Game 5.
The Mets are cautious about using Syndergaard on Sunday because he warmed up several times before his relief appearance Thursday, but he said he his arm has "never felt better." He also is gaining a better feel for what the playoffs are like.
"The anticipation was the game was going to be completely different, but in reality it's still the same game," Syndergaard said. "The only thing that's really different is the crowd's a little bit louder."
As Arrieta readies for his third playoff start, he also has learned a few things, particularly about conserving his mental energy before games. He said he tries to push his routine back, even just 10 to 15 minutes, to help conserve energy.
"You start to get that anxious energy, that excitement," Arrieta said. "Trying to find a way to relax and calm that down before you get to the ballpark (is important) because once your routine starts, it's hard to keep the energy level low.
"The physical toll really hasn't bothered me at all, but the mental side of it and all the energy you burn leading up to the game does have a little bit of effect. Having a couple of (playoff starts) under my belt now, I'm pretty confident I'll be able to handle that pretty well."
The Mets plan to send Jacob deGrom and Steven Matz out for Games 3 and 4 at Wrigley Field.
